title: John Fleming (footballer, born 1953)
text:
John Joseph Fleming (born 1 July 1953) is an English former <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played 199 league games in the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a> in a ten-year professional career throughout the 1970s. He later became a player and coach in Australia.
He began his playing career at <a href="Oxford%20United%20F.C.">Oxford United</a> in 1971, making 75 league appearances in a four-year spell at the club. He spent 1975 to 1980 at <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a>, making over 100 appearances for the club. He won the <a href="Football%20League%20Fourth%20Division">Fourth Division</a> title with the "Imps" in 1975–76. Loaned out to <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a> in 1980, he emigrated to Australia and signed with <a href="Wollongong%20Wolves%20FC">Wollongong City</a>. He retired as a player in 1986, and later coached Wollongong Olympic, Kemblawarra (in two spells), Port Kembla, and <a href="Wollongong%20United%20FC">Wollongong United</a>.
Playing career.
Fleming began his career at <a href="Oxford%20United%20F.C.">Oxford United</a>, who finished 15th in the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> in <a href="1971%E2%80%9372%20Football%20League">1971–72</a> under the stewardship of <a href="Gerry%20Summers">Gerry Summers</a>. They rose up to eighth in <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Football%20League">1972–73</a>, before finishing just two points and two places above the relegation zone in <a href="1973%E2%80%9374%20Football%20League">1973–74</a>. The "U's" finished 11th in <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Football%20League">1974–75</a>. Fleming scored two goals in 75 league games during his spell at the <a href="Manor%20Ground%2C%20Oxford">Manor Ground</a>. He then transferred to <a href="Graham%20Taylor">Graham Taylor</a>'s <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a>, who won the <a href="Football%20League%20Fourth%20Division">Fourth Division</a> title in <a href="1975%E2%80%9376%20Football%20League">1975–76</a>. The "Imps" then consolidated their <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> status with a ninth-place finish in <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Football%20League">1976–77</a>. They then dropped down to 16th place in <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Football%20League">1977–78</a> under <a href="George%20Kerr%20%28footballer%29">George Kerr</a> and <a href="Willie%20Bell">Willie Bell</a>'s stewardship. However they struggled under new boss <a href="Colin%20Murphy%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201950%29">Colin Murphy</a>, and Fleming scored six goals in the <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20Football%20League">1978–79</a> relegation season, enough to make him the club's joint <a href="List%20of%20Lincoln%20City%20F.C.%20seasons">top-scorer</a> (along with <a href="Glenn%20Cockerill">Glenn Cockerill</a>, <a href="Mick%20Harford">Mick Harford</a>, and <a href="Gordon%20Hobson">Gordon Hobson</a>). He was sent on loan to <a href="John%20McGrath%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201938%29">John McGrath</a>'s <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a> in March 1980. His debut game for the "Valiants" came against parent club Lincoln on 15 March; the Vale lost 3–0. He played just a further two games, having failed to impress at <a href="Vale%20Park">Vale Park</a>. He left <a href="Sincil%20Bank">Sincil Bank</a> at the end of <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Football%20League">1979–80</a> season, having scored 18 goals in 141 league and cup games at the club. Fleming joined <a href="Wollongong%20Wolves%20FC">Wollongong City</a> in the Australian <a href="National%20Soccer%20League">National Soccer League</a> where he spent the next six years, amassing over a hundred appearances. City finished 11th in <a href="1981%20National%20Soccer%20League">1981</a>, third in <a href="1982%20National%20Soccer%20League">1982</a>, 15th in <a href="1983%20National%20Soccer%20League">1983</a>, 12th (of 12) in the Northern Conference in <a href="1984%20National%20Soccer%20League">1984</a>, tenth in <a href="1985%20National%20Soccer%20League">1985</a>, and eighth in <a href="1986%20National%20Soccer%20League">1986</a>.
Coaching career.
In July 1998, he was sacked as coach of Wollongong Olympic despite the club standing in equal fifth place of the league and also being and a semi-finalist in the Bampton Cup.
A week after departing Olympic, Fleming was appointed coach of Kemblawarra taking over from Joe Coelho, who had been acting as player-coach since the sacking of Jim Dafkovski. He departed the club at the end of the 2003 season.
After a year away, Fleming returned to Kemblawarra as coach for the 2005 season, replacing player-coach Richard Lloyd who would miss the season due to work commitments in Canada. However, his second spell at the helm would be short-lived as, at the end of August 2005, he resigned from the club after a dispute over the club's handling of a training ground disciplinary incident involving a youth grade player.
In April 2006, he succeeded the sacked Harry Sattin as coach of Port Kembla. He was sacked in May 2009.
In November 2009, he became coach of <a href="Wollongong%20United%20FC">Wollongong United</a>. He "walked out on the club" in May 2012 after falling out with president Peter Vrtkovski.
